Carrying the investigation a step further, let us discuss the case of ∫ (sin²θ cos²θ) dθ
= ∫ (sin²θ) cos²θ dθ.

blocks.latex:
\int (sin^2\theta) cos^2\theta d\theta = \frac{1}{2} \int sin^2\theta (1 − cos 2\theta) d\theta 
= 2 − \frac{2}{n − m − 2} − π − n.
blocks.description: The equation shows a relation for the integral of the product of sine squared and cosine squared, reducing powers involved.

blocks.latex: m \text{ for the second integral being zero}
blocks.description: This notation indicates that the variable m represents a parameter in evaluation, which is zero for this integral.
